name: Teknologi for integrerte operasjoner og semantisk web

questions.question: [C# and .NET] Which of the following best describes the Common Language Specification (CLS)?
answers: A set of features guaranteed to be in most .NET languages to allow interoperability.
The specification of a new, common programming language for .NET, like C# and Visual Basic.
The set of features common to the C# and Java programming languages
A short version of the C# language specification, including only the most common and popular features.

questions.question: [C# and .NET] Which of the following are true about structures in C#
answers: Structs are passed by reference and do not allow inheritance.
Structs are passed by reference, and allow inheritance.
Structs are passed by value, and do not allow inheritance.
Structs are passed by value and allow inheritance.

questions.question: [C# and .NET] Which of the following describes the access modifier protected
answers: Accessible only within the same class.
Accessible only within same class and in any derived classes.
Accessible only within the same class and from derived classes within the same assembly.
Accessible only within classes in the same assembly.
Accessible from anywhere.

questions.question: [C# and .NET] When is the finally block in a C# try-catch loop executed
answers: Only if the try block has executed without errors being raised.
Only if the try block raised an error and a catch block for the error has been executed.
Only if the try block has raised an error which has not been handled.
After the try and catch block, no matter if an error was raised or not.

questions.question: [C# and .NET] How do you invoke a destructor in C#?
answers: You don't. The .NET runtime automatically calls the destructor of an object when it is garbage collected.
By using the delete keyword (delete myObj;).
By setting a variable pointing to the object to null (myObject = null;).
C# does not have destructors.

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What will the following code print if it is run?
answers: “win”.
“fail”.
The answer depends on the architecture of the computer (32 or 64 bit).
The code does not compile and cannot be run; nothing is printed.

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What is an assembly, and what does it contain?
answers: A Visual Studio project file. It contains the information about the project and how it should be assembled.
A file from the Base Class Library (BCL). It contains methods that can be used by others.
A collection of source code files in the Assembly language. These are the files that are used by the Common Language Specification.
A DLL file that is made from compiling source code. It contains the MSIL code that is run by the Common Language Runtime, metadata about the code and any resources needed.

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What is Silverlight?
answers: A cross-browser, cross-platform implementation of the .NET Framework for building and delivering rich internet applications.
A framework for building Windows and Xbox games that can utilize DirectX.
A plugin for Visual Studio that allows the user to build web sites.
A toolkit that allows the creation of modern multimedia user interfaces.

questions.question: [WCF] A web service is...
answers: An application that can communicate with other applications using SIP.
An application, accessible trough standard internet protocols, designed for machine to machine interaction
An application that can run on both Linux servers and Windows desktops.
A program allowing two or more people to communicate using video and/or audio.

questions.question: [WCF] Which of the following best describes what Windows Communication Foundation is?
answers: A programming framework for .NET used to build applications that inter-communicate.[1]
A set of amongst others, classes, assemblies and tools that enables design, implementation and runtime for communication on the .NET framework.[2]
An extension to the JIT compiler that enables it to compile web services.[3]
Microsoft’s primary implementation of the HTTP protocol[4]
None of these
1 and 2
1, 2 and 4

questions.question: [WCF] A WCF service must expose one or more endpoints. An endpoint consists of...
answers: Address, Binding and Source Code
Address, Binding and Contract
Binding, Network and Interface
WSDL, UDDI and SOAP

questions.question: [WCF] SOAP is used for...
answers: Contract definitions
Message Exchange
Service Discovery
Service Provider Discovery
Plugin for your shower

questions.question: [WCF] Choose four (pretend to): When designing service oriented applications, and as a base for WCF, four principles are important. Which?
answers: Only the schema, not the classes themselves should be relied upon when interacting with services.
Services allow us to reuse classes and their behavior across multiple systems.
Services and clients agree on an interface between them, but are otherwise completely independent.
Services and their clients are tightly coupled and should be developed together using the same programming languages and operating systems.
Boundaries between systems are explicit, and the client should actively chose to consume a service.
The fact that a service is not part of the local system should be hidden in order to avoid confusion and reduce cluttered source code.
All services should use the same protocols in order to allow every consumer to communicate with it.
Use policy-based compatibility to automatically determine how a consumer and a service should talk to each other.

questions.question: [Windows Workflow Foundation] In state machine workflows, can states be nested? I.e. can a state contain other states?
answers: Yes
No
Only if the workflow is not defined to be long-lived
Only if the workflow is defined using XML

questions.question: [Windows Workflow Foundation] In state machine workflows, can states be repeated? I.e. can you go from state A to B, then back to A?
answers: Yes
No
Only if the workflow is not defined to be long-lived
Only if the workflow is a console application

questions.question: [Windows Workflow Foundation] Which alternative best describes how a workflow is executed?
answers: The workflow is compiled as a program that can be run by double clicking on it.
The workflow is compiled into many smaller programs, one for each activity. All of them are started and they communicate using inter process communication.
The workflow is run by the WF runtime engine library which can be used in most any application to host a workflow.
A workflow is run from within Visual Studio only.
None of these.

questions.question: [Windows Workflow Foundation] In addition to be created using the visual designer or a programming language, workflows can also be defined using...
answers: The XML based language XAML (eXtensible Application Markup Language).
Comma Separated Values in a plain text file.
Windows Presentation Foundation
None of these

questions.question: [RTC] Real Time Communication is...
answers: Asynchronous, same place
Asynchronous, different place
Synchronous, same place
Synchronous, different place

questions.question: [RTC] SIP is used for...
answers: Setup, management and teardown of sessions as well as transferring the actual data.
Transferring files.
Transferring live audio and video.
Setup, management and teardown of sessions.
None of the above.

questions.question: [RTC] Which of the following statements are true for RTP?
answers: RTP contains information about the real-time session so applications can easily adjust for jitter, improper packet sequencing, and dropped packets.[1]
Each RTP packet contains one or more media payloads and other relevant information, such as time stamps and sequence numbers.[2]
RTP replaces UDP in order to avoid latencies caused by packet loss.[3]
RTP requires the use of UDP as transport protocol.[4]
1 and 2
1 and 3
2 and 3

questions.question: [SemWeb Intro] What is a correct statement about the Semantic Web?
answers: The Semantic Web is the formal specification of the semantic layer of the current web
The Semantic Web is an extension of the current web
The Semantic Web is a replacement of the current syntactic web
The Semantic Web is an application that manages web resources
The Semantic Web is a tool for building ontologies

questions.question: [SemWeb Intro] What is represented at the transport/syntax level of the Semantic Web stack of languages?
answers: URIs/Namespaces
XML/XMLS
RDF
RDFS
OWL

questions.question: [SemWeb Intro] Interoperability is central to the Semantic Web.  What languages support structural interoperability?
answers: XML only
OWL only
RDF only
XML and RDF
RDF and OWL

questions.question: [SemWeb Intro] What is not a full URI reference?
answers: http://www.restaurant.org/food#pizza
http://www.restaurant.org/food
isbn:1348229#item4
food-rest#pizza

questions.question: [SemWeb Intro] What are the four main ontology applicatin scenarios described in Jasper & Uschold: "A Framework for Understanding and Classifying Ontology Applications"?
answers: Ontology as specification, common access to information, ontology-based search, and neutral authoring
Human communication, data access via shared ontology, data access via mapped ontology, and shared services
Application, task, domain and upper-level models
Common access to information, shared services, authoring ontologies, and ontology-based search
Authoring, accessing, sharing, and search

questions.question: [Ontology languages] At which level of the Semantic Web stack do we introduce classes?
answers: RDF
XML
RDFS
OWL

questions.question: [Ontology languages] What does RDFS stand for?
answers: Resource Description Framework Scheme
Resource Domain Framework Specification
Resource Description Foundation Scheme
Resource Domain Formal Specification

questions.question: [Ontology languages] What is not possible to define in RDF/RDFS?
answers: Only persons can own cars
A car driver is a subclass of both person and adult
Peter is a car driver
Peter does not own cars
Peter owns cars

questions.question: [Ontology languages] Which ontology language is the most expressive?
answers: UML class diagrams
RDFS
WordNet
OWL DL
OWL Full

questions.question: [OWL Modelling] X is an individual of class Y, that is not equal to the top-most class Thing.  What is true about X?
answers: X is a subclass of Y
All instances of X are also instances of Y
X can be an instance of a class Z that is different from and not a superclass of Y
X only inherits properties from Y
X does not need to be an instance of Thing

questions.question: [OWL Modelling] X is an individual of class Y, that is not equal to the top-most class Thing.  What is not true about X?
answers: X is an instance of Y
X inherits all properties of Y
X is an instance of at least one other class than Y.
X’s subclasses inherits all properties of Y
X may be identical to another individual W

questions.question: [OWL Modelling] What is not true about classes in OWL DL?
answers: Classes may not have any instances
A class may be the instance of another class
There is only one class that is not the subclass of any other class
Classes may be defined as the complement of other classes

questions.question: [OWL Modelling] What is a potential relationship between hasBrother and hasSibling?
answers: hasBrother is a subclass of hasSibling
hasBrother is an instance of hasSibling
hasBrother is a subproperty of hasSibling
hasSibling is the range of hasBrother
hasSibling is the domain of hasBrother

questions.question: [OWL Modelling] What is correct about two disjoint classes X and Y?
answers: X and Y do not have any common superclasses
X and Y do not have common properties
An individual cannot be an intance of both X and Y
A class Z can have both X and Y as superclasses
Disjoint classes have no instances

questions.question: [OWL Modelling] How would you define the object property isFatherOf?
answers: Functional and transitive
Symmetric and functional
Symmetric and inverse functional
Transitive and inverse functional
Symmetric and transitive

questions.question: [Abstract OWL Syntax ] What can we infer from these statements?
answers: All students are intellectuals
All professors are intellectuals
Students do not write papers
Professors may be students
John is not a student

questions.question: [Ontology Engineering] What is the different between ontology engineering and ontology learning?
answers: Ontology engineering is manual ontology building. Ontology learning is automatic ontology building.
Ontology engineering is the discipline of building ontologies.  Ontology learning is a subdiscipline of ontology engineering
Ontology learning is the discipline of adapting a ontology engineering methods to concrete modeling tasks
Ontology learning and ontology engineering are synonomous.

questions.question: [Ontology Engineering] What is the purpose of tf.idf scores in ontology learning?
answers: Tf.idf scores identify which terms may be candidate concepts in ontologies
Tf.idf scores separate terms into classes, individuals and properties
Tf.idf scores disambiguate related terms
Tf.idf scores identify hierarhical relationships between concepts

questions.question: [Reasoning] What is an interpretation of an ontology in Description Logic?
answers: A population of an ontology with instances of all classes and properties
A domain of real-world objects
The common understanding of the stakeholders building the ontology
A possible world that materializes the ontology
